description: From Middle French modal, from Medieval Latin modālis (“pertaining to a mode”), from Latin modus (“mode”); equivalent to mode +‎ -al. Compare to French, Spanish, and Portuguese modal and Italian modale.

adjectives.description: modal (comparative more modal, superlative most modal)

entries.meaning: Of, or relating to a mode or modus.
(grammar) Of, relating to, or describing the mood of a clause.
(music) Of, relating to, or composed in the musical modi by which an octave is divided, associated with emotional moods in Ancient — and in medieval ecclesiastical — music.
(logic) Of, or relating to the modality between propositions.
(computing) Having separate modes in which user input has different effects.
(graphical user interface) Requiring immediate user interaction and thus presented so that it cannot be closed or interacted behind until a decision is made.
examples: a modal dialog; a modal window

entries.meaning: (metaphysics) Relating to the form of a thing rather to any of its attributes.
(linguistics) A modal form, notably a modal auxiliary.

examples: Using the same type of distributional criterion, we could argue that only a Verb (in its base form) can occur in the position marked — in (23) below to complete the sentence:(23)     They/it can —[...]Conversely, the only type of word which could be used to begin a three-word sentence such as (25) below:(25)     — I be frank?is a Modal: cf. [...]

entries.meaning: (graphical user interface) A modal window, one that cannot be closed until a decision is made.
examples: Modal screen elements are subtrees which, when activated, disable all elements external to them. Examples of modals are yes-no message boxes and the application itself.
